'Drone overflights are testing our defense capabilities,' says French military intelligence and security chief
subhead: Despite heightened vigilance from his teams, General Aymeric Bonnemaison, director of the French military security agency, admits that it remains difficult to identify the culprits of suspicious incidents. Since September, there has been a sharp increase in drone overflights of military installations.
byline: Interview by Chloé Hoorman and Elise Vincent

New batch of Epstein files contains multiple Trump references
subhead: The US president is featured prominently in the thousands of documents that were just published, underlining his close ties to Jeffrey Epstein. The Justice Department issued a statement shortly after the files dropped, saying some documents "contain untrue and sensationalist claims made against President Trump."

title: Israel NGO registration rules could lead to collapse of aid into Gaza
subhead: New administrative rules imposed on international organizations have already led to the exclusion of several groups from the Palestinian enclave. Humanitarian actors say they are deeply concerned for civilians.

title: A 'two-headed' art market in 2025
subhead: In 2025, art market professionals observed a sharp divide between the sluggish mood of the first half of the year and the fireworks of the November sales in New York.

title: White, snowy Christmas: The truth behind a misleading cliché
subhead: Long associated with imagery of the Three Wise Men, the depiction of Christmas took on a wintry turn in the 16th century. Yet the chances of seeing snow in France on December 25 have never been lower.

title: Is Paris finally embracing musical theater?
subhead: Long considered unpopular by the French, musicals have flourished recently in the capital. But is this just a mere trend to which the French will inevitably turn their noses up?
byline: By Sandrine Blanchard and Rosita Boisseau

title: From Barbie to Labubu, adults find comfort in collectible figurines
subhead: The craze for Funko Pop! and other Blind Box collectibles has continued to grow, driven by a generation of 'kidults,' adults who embrace their inner child, turning their homes into miniature pop culture museums. Caught between a search for identity, a significant budget and environmental contradictions, this new hobby has become a mainstream phenomenon.
